This game is the perfect balance of arcade-realism. If you liked older COD titles such as MW2 (the original from 2009) this is a brilliant game to try when on sale. Movement is slow but smooth and balanced as people that try and drop shot or bunny hop will get a huge delay before firing or aiming. Weapon handling feels very smooth and the TTK is quick, no player is a bullet sponge. Some people may find this frustrating by being sniped by someone hiding with an AR on semi-auto or someone shredding you up close almost instantly. You want to play this game by flanking and getting the first shot on as most AR's are 2 shot kill (to the chest and above, 1 shot headshot, shooting limbs also may take an extra bullet)

Most of the maps are a very nice size and well designed. Some maps are poor but no game has a perfect map selection. Insurgency SS is not a walking simulator (unlike squad). The proximity chat is also hilarious at times but some people do LARP. The enemy can also hear you in proxy chat. Graphically the game is also stunning and you do not need a NASA PC as it runs very well. 90% of the cosmetics are very cool and realistic for both factions. 

Console cross-play has been added now too which is nice and hopefully keeps the game alive until their next project. If you're a Battlefield player who plays Rush/ Breakthrough you will enjoy a game-mode called "Push" which is similar in extending the map when an objective is captured.

Insurgency: Sandstorm remains one of the most well-made and realistic tactical shooters on the market. Its core gameplay is incredibly satisfying and immersive. However, it feels held back by two significant issues.

Firstly, the lack of substantial content updates in recent years has left the community wanting more from its potential. Secondly, and more critically, the death cam mechanic that reveals your position upon being killed severely undermines the Sniper and Machine Gunner roles. This feature punishes strategic positioning and long-range play, making these classes disproportionately reliant on team coordination to be effective.

Ultimately, Sandstorm is a fantastic game that seems to have been underappreciated, even by its own developers. It's a title with immense potential that deserves more attention and thoughtful design adjustments.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour ‚Äì 500 g
Water ‚Äì 200 ml
Egg ‚Äì 1
Salt ‚Äì 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes ‚Äì 1 kg
Onions ‚Äì 2
Lard or butter ‚Äì 50 g
Salt ‚Äì to taste
Ground black pepper ‚Äì to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Saut√© the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the saut√©ed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or saut√©ed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

This game is really good in gunplay, the guns are all pretty fun and realistic, and have very fun and cool details (ie. shooting the 50. too much gives you tinnitus) and there are plenty of fun modes and theres always new gamemodes in rotation. The customization of guns is also really nice with lots of options and customizability and the points system also keeps things balanced. The class system also gives new levels of teamwork between players needing to rely on each other to beat enemies, and balanced as it limits the number of people who can play each class. The best thing is probably no shitty or predatory monetization, you buy the game and theres no microtransactions, all dlc's are purely cosmetic. 

The main thing that would turn away new players, and me sometimes is the crappy community, especially the higher level players, a lot of whom are sweats and very obnoxious and condescending towards newer players, their just overall very toxic. Even minor mistakes like hurting them once will have them full on killing you and yelling at you in voicechat. Most of them fail at proper teamworking and just yell in vc most of the time. Disable vc or just play the PvE gamemodes is probably what I recommend. 

the community and playerbase is also pretty small, but I've never had issues with queuing into a lobby within a minute. The PvE alone makes the game pretty worth it.

also, my message to the devs would to please add a balancing system on both teams, it kinda sucks when its 10 level ten to hundred bronzes vs 10 level 800 to 4000 silvers and diamonds

all in all, I would only recommend buying the game when its on sale for like 10$ or something, but its pretty decent, ruined by the toxic players, solid 6.5/10

How do you solve a content drought problem that stemmed from catering to competitive play, then transitioning towards console inclusion, then treating it like a live service game amidst the single update once per year that comes with a singular new gun per team, and maybe a new map?

Cosmetic MTX supplementing that singular yearly update.
Cosmetics, cosmetics, cosmetics.
Sure, they might be cheap (they used to cost more iirc), but they release so much more superficial paid content than actual game content at this rate. Btw, the total cost for all cosmetics on Steam at the time of writing this is around $200 CDN. Too much? Don't worry, they gradually release "(X) Editions" every year that have all the cosmetics of the previous years and nothing else.

Oh, and pepper in a couple 3x XP weekends for a completely meaningless level system that has absolutely zero progression past lv. 20 (when you unlock the Commander role). And also make some innovative(?) gamemodes limited time for no real reason other than an attempt at FOMO, I guess.

Some of the best assets and audiowork in the FPS genre (to the point where people port the assets and audio to many other games), and a really, really strong start that swiftly lost any and all momentum. Only a couple thousand die-hard fans still play it (peak being 3.9k over the last year, but averages around 2.0k~), and they're spread across each mode. It's sad, really, because this used to be a comfort game for me, and then they just gave up completely.
